thefatbombus: Thank you thank you thank you
fatfeministmich: It’s so absurd, I remember starting to feel ashamed of my belly at like age 8-9. I was a skinny kid, but of course like girls do, my stomach had a rounded shape at the bottom. And that stuck with me forever. The more weight I gained, the bigger my belly got, and I hated it more and more. It’s taken a lot of hard work over the last two years to get to a point where I don’t hate it anymore! I don’t love it either, but I try to be in a neutral relationship with it. And I am aware of how political my belly is and I use it. I wear clothing that shows it clearly and I don’t try to hide it. Because god damn why should I?! Everyone needs to see all the different body shapes that exists.
amysalloway: @dammitphilomena Exactly exactly this. Ditto for me. Pear-shaped large people are seen as attractive and acceptable...apples are not. That's been like insult on top of injury for me. If I had seen apple-shaped bodies being worthy of love at any time in my life, my body image might be far less negative and punishing.
highballemy19: Yes I do think my life would have been different. qimzel: My life would be 100% different!! I always got comments from everyone around me, close or not, about my weight.. meltybrain: Yes. Allllll the yes. I want my kids to see alllll the beautiful bodies. I didn’t. All I was exposed to was negativity and that has impacted me so much, in so many ways. I want to show my daughter and tell her how joyful you look.
inconvenientlyhuman: Yes definitely! So far I do it in the way I talk about my own body and other peoples bodies. I want her to not only grow up confident that her own body is okay, whatever size and shape that may be, but also to be an ally and know everyone else is okay whatever size and shape they are, and automatically see people beyond their bodies rather than that being a first point of judgement, which is what it still is in society today. zords_wifiu: My son weighed in at 12 lbs when he was born (T1D for added adventures!) so my belly is sorta double, my abs bisected to make room for him so they sit off to the sides and the skin is really soft and stretched, I had well over 100 stretch marks that were angry and red and sore after he was born. peachstunnly: This photo feels like snuggling my comforter in the morning with the sun shining through 💛

jen.allyson: I Iove bellies so much too! So soft and comforting. ❤️
angie.w.74: Growing up I saw men's bellies but never women's bellies unless they were flat and perfect. What's funny is I'm attracted to a nice soft belly on a man and loathe my body. I wonder how I would feel about my body if I saw women's soft bellies?
tricksypixiemeg: I love this photo. You look so serene 💖
fairiesandfancies: I love this picture and peace on your face 💜
seafoam_films: YES!! So so much yes. 👏👏👏 Beautiful ✨✨✨
sossitywrites: yes. and thank you so very much 💖
grasping_at_straws_: Yes!!! I remember HATING myself as a kid. Even in first grade because I was always bigger and there was no representation of fat bodies or if there was they were always the butt of the joke. It took years, a massive eating disorder and two kids before I finally woke up and said “hey this body is a GOOD BODY. You have literally put it through hell and it’s still performing, still going strong and it doesn’t deserve this. “ And slowly I stopped differentiating between me and my body. And now I love myself, all of me and I try so hard to watch how I speak and act in front of my children and what they are exposed to because I don’t ever want them to feel that deep shame and sadness I felt. Anyways I came to your comments just to tell you thank you. You are appreciated and amazing. And thank you for reminding us to be present and mindful and grateful and kind to ourselves and others. 💗
alifereframed: So different. I literally cannot imagine growing up seeing diverse bodies. I think it would have changed my life.
staccmarie: 💜💜💜💜😭😭😭😭 thank you for teaching us ti embrace our bellies!!!
debicet: I can’t explain how much it has helped me 💜💜💜. Thank you for your willingness to be vulnerable with us all
aelurine: Forgetting other people look like me has been detrimental to my mental health
tracyx127: That’s the hardest part for me to love is my belly. I’ve accepted my chubby thighs and fat arms. My belly is what holds me back most days.
chriscrawford71592: Yo this is so important. I only saw one body that's like mine and that was my dad. He represented everything I wanted to be and that changed when he died...but I see people like you carrying on the same type of kindness and self love that he had and it gives me hope that maybe I'm not as flawed as I thought 😊.
katharyn_weddington: You are such an inspiration! Absolutely beautiful!! 💕
bubacarrdrammehg: So is it possible to reduce it ? #if not is all good just be happy with it
nicholekoonce: Your belly was one of the first that I saw when I redid my feed to only follow body positive grams. I had always been so ashamed of my body...never allowing myself or lovers to touch my belly...as if it wasn't a part of me. I have a similar shape as you and to see you in all of your beauty helped me see it in myself. Thank you for inspiring my belly love. There is nothing more enjoyable than cuddling with my husband and him rubbing my underappreciated belly. You are an inspiration lady, to far more than you realize. Thank you for being bold and helping me to do the same!!
princesskyra_bbw: Watching Lizzo perform, I cry every time. To see a body that represents mine doing something that I wish I could have done. It's so amazing. And I'm so thankful for the new generation of women and also the fat women who have finally realize they can be free and let go. I'm so so thankful to all of the pioneers who are finally getting us representation, because young fat women are going to grow up with so much more self-esteem than you were I ever got to grow up with. And the world is going to be better for it. Thank you for sharing your beauty with us💜
nikki.clemmer: 😍 mind if i use this photo for a painting reference?
tfbtay: Don’t feel like I’m fat enough to be fat & beautiful . Don’t feel like I’m thin enough to be thin & beautiful 😬
hlbarnes: I think your belly is amazing and beautiful! I have also spent WAY TOO many years ashamed of my midsection. I have never in my life had a flat stomach and used to feel like this was something wrong about me. If I had seen bellies growing up it would have made a huge difference!! Seeing bellies as an adult has given me the courage to love myself and my belly. I wear crop tops now and no longer fear my "belly line" in clothes. You have been a part of that for me, so thank you!! ✨💖

rosemaryandquartz: You are such a babe!! Such an inspiring badass babe!
theselemonstho: I think my life would have been a LOT different. Especially if the only uncovered big belly I saw (my mother's, let's be real) wasn't self-shamed constantly.
